qas.question: What trait is the most common way of determining if languages are dialects?
What is the term for when dialects A and B are mutually intelligible, dialect B and C are mutually intelligible, but dialects A and C are not mutually intelligible?
What is the definition of mutual intelligibility?

answers.text: if being a speaker of one variety confers sufficient knowledge to understand and be understood by a speaker of the other

qas.question: Which is the most uncommon and purely linguistic criterion?
What is the term for two dialects of different languages that are intertwined?
What occurs when dialect A B and C are all mutual intelligible with another?
Which is the most uncommon criterion for being a dialect of the same language?

context: The most common, and most purely linguistic, criterion is that of <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0><b6_0>mutual intelligibility<b6_0/><b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/>: two varieties are said to be dialects of the same language <a2_0>if being a speaker of one variety confers sufficient knowledge to understand and be understood by a speaker of the other<a2_0/>; otherwise, they are said to be different languages. However, this definition becomes problematic in the case of <a1_0><b5_0>dialect continua<b5_0/><a1_0/>, in which it may be the case that dialect B is mutually intelligible with both dialect A and dialect C but dialects A and C are not mutually intelligible with each other. In this case the criterion of mutual intelligibility makes it impossible to decide whether A and C are dialects of the same language or not. Cases may also arise in which a speaker of dialect X can understand a speaker of dialect Y, but not vice versa; the mutual intelligibility criterion flounders here as well.
